body: BEFORE they decided to build the Boulder Creek Steakhouse chain together, its founders considered whether their nearly lifelong friendship could survive the challenges that a business partnership inevitably brings. title: L.I. @ WORK; Partners Who Run a Different Sort of Steakhouse

body: AT New Kasturi Pavilion, a Bangladeshi restaurant on Lexington Avenue near 26th Street, cabdrivers from around New York gather to eat, talk, take bathroom breaks and play chess. Their conversation usually includes gossip, news of friends and family, and, of course, the challenges of life behind the wheel. But tonight the conversation has taken a
title: Driving a Different Kind of Hack

body: ON oceanfront land in Brooklyn once occupied by the Brighton Beach Baths, the Muss Organization of Queens is moving into the third year of construction on a condominium project that is reversing the symbolism of the site -- from one linked with the past to one reflecting the possibilities the city holds for its recent immigrants and their children.
title: On Brighton Beach, a Tide of Immigrants

title: Paid Notice: Deaths AMES, LAWRENCE DR.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; Dreams Interrupted or Not Yet Lived, Great Photos Never to Be Taken

body: At first glance, the European American Bank on Broad Hollow Road in Melville, on Long Island, seemed like a typical suburban retail branch. There were teller windows and safe deposit boxes. title: U.S. Arrests 7 in Mafia Use of a Bank on L.I.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; A Dream Fulfilled, a Devoted Father and a Mother With No Answers

body: For Cantor Fitzgerald, the brokerage firm devastated by the World Trade Center attacks, it was yet another piece of bad news. title: Friend Stole Tower Victim's Card, Police Charge

body: There were 1,500 pigeons packed into traveling crates, and the Knights of Columbus taproom smelled like a barn. It was race night and the birdmen talked to one another about storm fronts and prevailing winds. They talked to their birds. They synchronized their race clocks and tagged their pigeons with numbered rubber bands. They drifted toward the
title: They Don't Brake for Statues; Racing Pigeons Hurry Home to Brooklyn, at 55 M.P.H.

body: The classified advertisement starts with an announcement: ''Public Notice to Victims of the Gambino Organized Crime Family and Salvatore 'Sammy the Bull' Gravano.'' title: Questions Persist on How to Allot Profit From 'Underboss'

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; A Bank Analyst Who Loved to Fish, and an Aunt Who Loved Salsa

body: Fifty years ago, Ronny Buchman was a messenger for a company that, among other things, made recordings for Voice of America. His friend Allen Schwartz was in his freshman year at City College. They were Giants fans living a block apart deep in Dodgers territory, in Bensonhurst. ''Baseball ruled our lives,'' said Buchman, who became a Giants fan
title: BASEBALL; Another Thomson Record

body: New York City public schools are being run this year largely by a corps of inexperienced leaders, with two out of every three principals having less than five years of experience on the job and 36 percent having less than two years. The lack of seasoned leaders, the worst shortage in decades, could not have come at a worse time, school officials
title: Increasingly, The Principal Is a Newcomer

body: JAMES MADISON HIGH SCHOOL was built 75 years ago to serve the growing families of the surrounding area when much of the farmland there was giving way to urbanization. The resulting rectangular blocks would end up almost exclusively residential, some of them featuring the spacious Spanish-style terrace homes for which the area is known. The high
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Madison, Brooklyn; Spacious, Gracious and Close to School

body: At a conference for hairstylists in Miami Beach last June, Natalya Chertkova learned that one way to build a strong following was to make sure that customers remembered your name. So earlier this month, Ms. Chertkova ordered black plastic name tags so that she and the stylists she worked with could mount them on their mirrors. The name tags arrived
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: CHARITY; Hairstylist Is Left Without Job or Tools

author: Additional reporting was provided by Erika Kinetz.
body: UNTIL this month, the Gullen family loved being typical. The four of them live in Forest Hills, Queens, where for 22 years they have rented the same dim apartment on a leafy street with birdbaths and lawn jockeys. They are big coffee drinkers. They know all their neighbors. Paul Gullen is a snowy-haired English professor at Hofstra University in
title: Untouched, But Touched

body: MICHAEL LOMONACO says he owes his survival to a miracle. As the top chef at Windows on the World, he normally arrived at his 106th-floor kitchen at 8:15 each morning. But on Sept. 11, having arrived at the World Trade Center a few minutes earlier than usual, he stopped at a Lens Crafters in the shopping concourse to have his eyes checked so he
title: CHANGED LIVES; A Chef Who Wants to Reunite His Cooking Family

body: We played badly on Monday the night before the attack. On Tuesday, the Loews corporate jet was grounded in Denver. I was champing at the bit to get back into action in New York. title: THE BOSS; The Call of the Native City

body: The primary election scheduled for Sept. 11 but postponed because of the terrorist attack will be held today. Absentee ballots submitted before Sept. 11 count, but votes cast at polling places that day do not. This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County. All are Democratic

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: CABBIES; Drivers Say They Risk Violence by Working, and May Even Lose Money

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; Parties, Love Notes and Other Small Memories That Now Loom Large

body: The first time the phone rang, Victoria Ehigiator was elbow deep in a sink of soapy dishes. She dried her hands and picked up the phone. It was Al Sharpton on the line, calling about the primary election. He said his piece, and she went back to the dishes. A few minutes later, the phone rang again, and she lifted herself from the bubbles once more.
title: CAMPAIGNING FOR MAYOR: THE VOTERS; City Voters Have Heard It All As Campaign Din Nears End

title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 09-09-01: PARALLELS; Knowing Her Place

''It said that there was an open casting call for someone to play Jason Alexander's son
title: Bensonhurst To Hollywood In One Leap For Actor, 17

body: One of the first lessons Alexandra and Nicolay Mazhirov learned when they came to the United States was that they had to think big. Mrs. Mazhirov had owned a small chocolate factory in Odessa, Russia, and her husband was its manager. They came to New York in 1992 and five years ago started selling chocolates to the Russians in Brooklyn, from a
title: FOOD STUFF; Chocolate Memories Of the Czars and Rasputin

body: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has assigned a superintendent to look into possible discrimination against Asian immigrant students at Lafayette High School in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, school officials said yesterday. Last September, five Chinese students beginning their senior year were forced to leave Lafayette without prior notice on the ground
title: Schools Official to Investigate Treatment of Asian Students

body: DIANA BELOZOVSKY was 13 when she and her parents set out on a complicated getaway from the Soviet Union. At the American Embassy in Rome, the girl's elementary-school English proved indispensable to her parents for the first time. ''This was very crucial,'' said Ms. Belozovsky, who is now 24. ''They were deciding whether we get to America or not.''
title: URBAN TACTICS; Translating for Parents Means Growing Up Fast

body: PASQUALE-Rose. 84 years old, a homemaker and a dress model. A lifelong resident of Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. She entered into eternal rest on August 24, 2001, at Maimonides. Born Rose Mascato in Manhattan, Mrs. Pasquale moved to Brooklyn at 12 years old. A graduate of Lincoln High School, she enjoyed cooking, entertaining, sewing and taking trips to
title: Paid Notice: Deaths PASQUALE, ROSE

body: Years ago, when I was a uniformed police officer in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, a man walked up to me at a school crossing and started speaking Italian. I couldn't understand him, so I sent him to find someone who could translate. At the same time, a woman approached, walking her dog. The dog brushed up against a pole and got a bad shock. That's what
title: MY JOB; My Daily Dose of Murder

body: SHOWING a degree of resilience in the face of the national economic slowdown, the residential real estate market in the New York metropolitan region clung to its penchant for price increases in the first half of the year, even as buyers became more choosy (or wary) and sellers lost a bit of their swagger. Though more moderate than during the frenzy
title: Home Prices Are Up, but Not as Much

author: Nicholas Dawidoff is the author of ''The Catcher Was a Spy'' and the editor of a coming Library of America anthology of baseball writing.
body: Fred Wilpon became a New York real-estate plutocrat, the builder of tall towers along gilded blocks of Manhattan avenues, by excelling at the art of the calculated risk. The grandson of an immigrant Brooklyn street peddler, Wilpon left Bensonhurst on a full scholarship to the University of Michigan, and by age 30, he was back in New York, betting
title: The House That Rudy Built

body: A six-day August heat wave came to a soggy end yesterday afternoon when thunderstorms descended on most of the region. But there was no letup for utilities, as the storm knocked down power lines and electricity was cut off at tens of thousands of households in the Northeast. Lightning and winds gusting at nearly 40 miles per hour in some places
title: Storms End Hot Spell, but Conjure Their Own Problems

body: Chinatown leaders say the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has failed to make good on its promise to ease disruption caused by the elimination of service at the Grand Street subway station. After months of protests, transit officials agreed to expand M train service at the Bowery Station from 9:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., when many workers in
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN; Deal on Subways Stops Short of Destinations, Riders Say

body: These Workaday Walls Are Made of Marble His lips were tight but his taste was lavish. Until he retired two years ago, Gus Bevona was the president of a major union of building-service workers in New York City, whose strikes stirred havoc in the 4,000 office and apartment buildings where its members were janitors, maintenance people and doormen. But
title: FOLLOWING UP

body: To follow the mayoral campaign of Peter Fortunate Vallone is to schlep out to the outer reaches of the so-called outer boroughs, to the decidedly unglamorous, solidly middle-class, largely white fringes of the city: Todt Hill on Staten Island, Floral Park and Bensonhurst in Brooklyn. His campaign aides, when learning of their next destination,
title: Vallone Maps Victory Route Through Giuliani Territory

body: A newly transplanted couple from Hoboken learned the easy way one recent Sunday why Bella Italia pork store and catering establishment in Monroe Township, Middlesex County, is developing a reputation as a personal-service store. ''We were clueless people asking for help,'' said Deborah Maston. ''They offered to pound out my chicken cutlets,'' she
title: QUICK BITE/Monroe Township; Over the Verrazano to Your Table

body: Dave Jorn, the stony-faced manager of the defending champion Yankees, claims not to see what the fuss is about. ''We're in first place and they're in first place,'' he said after batting practice. ''Other than that, there's no significance in it. It's just like playing another team.'' Luz Portoblanco, the cool-headed pitching ace of the Yankees'
title: A Rivalry Across the Narrows; First, the Subway Series; Now, Fans Take the Ferry

body: This is a tale about what it means to be a museum in the age of cyberspace. The Tigertail Virtual Museum is a Web site containing 5,000 famous works of art that Robert Uzgalis, the museum's director, has ''virtually restored.'' The works now look as he imagines they did at the time of their creation. Using software to alter images he has pulled
title: ARTS ONLINE; So Is It or Isn't It a Museum? Only the Web Suffix Knows

body: In the shadows of the Cyclone and Astroland, lit by a full moon nearly hidden by the neon green Nathan's sign, boxing arrived in Coney Island last night. On a night of fights at KeySpan Park, the new home of the Brooklyn Cyclones minor league baseball team, the show varied from local boxers hoping to make an impression on their own turf to the show
title: BOXING; Johnson Wins Unanimous Decision as Part of Lively Card in Brooklyn

body: When Wan Shan Hu was introduced as Lafayette High School's valedictorian at graduation last month, some parents in the the audience grumbled that it was always an immigrant who got the award. Others booed outright. Unfazed, Ms. Hu finished her valedictory speech in her accented English, a shy smile the only sign of how happy she was even to be at
title: Doing Battle to Stay in High School

body: ''This is one of the most famous roller coasters in the world,'' Lou DiBella said, pointing at the 74-year-old Cyclone at Coney Island a few days ago. ''Doesn't it look beat up to you? This neighborhood is beaten up. It's a depressing thing. Sort of like a crying clown.'' DiBella said he and his partners hoped the boxing card they are promoting
title: BOXING; Fight Night Follows Minor League Baseball to Brooklyn

author: Jeffrey Stanley, a playwright, is the author of ''Tesla's Letters,'' which was presented in 1999 by the Ensemble Studio Theater, and, most recently, ''UFOs Over Brooklyn.''

Where are you? 193: Yeah, roger. You got 193 on the Lower East. Roger? (loud static interference) CHICKENBOY: 193, come back with that. What's your 20? 193: Yeah, man. Come on. L-TRAIN:
title: Talk Radio

body: There was a baseball game in Brooklyn last night. It took 44 years to say this, but the professional game returned to the holy and haunted borough that was plundered after the 1957 season. The Brooklyn Cyclones, named for a roller coaster just to the east, opened with a 3-2 victory in 10 innings last night at their new $39 million publicly
title: Sports of The Times; Summer Rite Returns To Borough of Churches

body: EVEN people accused of committing bloody crimes for the mob have their supporters. While the authorities might consider a wiseguy nothing more than a heartless killer or a dead-eyed thug, his friends and relatives are just as likely to remember him as the kindly man who once helped an ailing neighbor with her groceries or the doting brother who was
title: Word for Word/Gangland Testimonials; Dear Judge, Joey Whatshisname Was a Well Respectable Guy

body: Sam Chwat, the dean of New York chat, roams the streets as a giant ear would, listening. A coach to Midwesterners, Southerners and other regional imports who want to talk New York for Broadway and film, he needs to hear, and often tape-record, the contours of each local accent, from Rosie Perez to Fran Drescher. ''My ears are always on duty,'' he
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK FOLKLORE; A Teacher of Newyorkese Who Taps the Power of Babel

body: Officially, of course, it will always be the B train. But just take it on any given Sunday evening, along about half of its southerly course, and you might agree that it would not be much of an exaggeration to give the subway line a subtitle: the Fish Train. ''Whoa, man, it smells like fish in here,'' said Ramon Vasquez, a hotel maintenance worker.
title: Tunnel Vision; Bags of Joy, Pungent And Lucky

body: MARTY JOLTIN, who owns the Printing Store in the careworn part of Times Square, insists that he long ago tucked away his dreams of fame and fortune. But ask him about the Vocal Lords, and he swiftly pulls from the chaos of his desk a black-and-white photograph of the four teenage singers from Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, all slick pompadours and genial
title: COPING; Back When Hair and Harmonies Were Slick

body: Susan and David Leeper are parents with their hands full, balancing two careers while caring for three children and a menagerie of cats, dogs and goats. They are usually on the run, shuttling between school, playdates, church services and karate lessons -- and the rural homestead they call Paradise Leep is a country mile from most conveniences,
title: The Fresh Air Fund; In Memory of a Father, An Invitation to Children

body: Medical treatment given to 13,500 city inmates is not improving as quickly as city officials had hoped when they hired a Tennessee-based, for-profit company six months ago to revamp medical and mental health services at Rikers Island, officials on an oversight board said yesterday. The death this week of a 37-year-old inmate who had to wait an hour
title: Panel Faults Progress of Prison Health Care

body: A sweep of escort services led to the arrests of 12 women and eight men on charges of prostitution and promoting prostitution, the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said yesterday. During a nine-month inquiry, undercover detectives telephoned escort services advertised in Russian-language newspapers and were directed to private houses
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 20 Charged With Prostitution

body: Four bus stops cut from the B82 line in Bensonhurst were restored last weekend, after hundreds of people protested the change. The bus had been rerouted because a new ramp to the Belt Parkway prevented it from making a left turn from Cropsey Avenue to Bay 52nd Street. But after the Transportation Department installed a left turn bay one block later
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN -- UPDATES; Stops Restored, Smiles Return

body: What with the bomb plot and the scrawled threats, the elegant mystery lady and the sober-suited gentlemen ringing his bell in the dead of night, Harry Rimmer still cannot quite believe the vastness of the conspiracy his friend and tenant, Akbar Shareef, constructed against him. Were it not for the pile of signed contracts and receipts saying things
title: A Complex, and Friendly, Protection Racket Unravels

body: From the very outset of the nostalgia- and memory-drenched ''Vocal Lords,'' a single question hangs in the air: What happened to separate two boyhood friends from Bensonhurst for some 40 years? In the answer lie considerations of dreams and destiny at the crossroads of life, and if the answer to the question is not swiftly delivered, Eric Winick's
title: THEATER REVIEW; Dreamers Meet Reality In Doo-Wop Harmony

body: Here is some advice you probably will not get from Ann Landers: Do not, under any circumstances, date the son of a gangster who has admitted to killing 19 men. If you do, you risk ending up like the girlfriend of Gerard Gravano, the 24-year-old son of Salvatore Gravano, the Gambino family hit man better known as Sammy the Bull. According to the
title: Reporter's Notebook; Going Out With a Mobster's Son? Follow the Code of Silence

body: When the mob melodrama ''The Sopranos'' sings its seasonal swan song tonight -- inducing withdrawal agita among millions of the show's hopelessly addicted viewers -- more than a few sighs of relief will be heard. Specifically, from restaurateurs and movie-house owners who have taken, um, a hit on Sunday nights during the 13-week HBO series. ''I'll
title: Drop the Knife and Fork. Tony Soprano Is On.

body: A 50-acre piece of land in East New York that is being developed into the Gateway Center shopping mall has had some good news to report lately, and it is not just that the long-dormant site has finally been cleared of its chin-high weeds. The property near Starrett City in Brooklyn is expected to house one of the largest suburban-style shopping
title: Commercial Real Estate; A Mall Planned for East New York Is 88% Leased

body: J & R Music World/Computer World, the electronics retailer with seven stores on Park Row, was unable to persuade city officials to designate part of the street J & R Row. But the effort cast a spotlight on a little-understood practice: the awarding of so-called street aliases. Each year, council members introduce dozens of bills to create aliases,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK STREETS; The Street Is Familiar, but Can't Remember the Nickname

body: THE real problem is not ''The Sopranos,'' the television mob opera, or all those movies and books showing vulgar Italian-Americans wolfing down pasta and working for the Mafia. The problem is that popular culture makes little room for defining Italian-Americans in other ways. And the best solution for Italian-Americans troubled by stereotypes is to
title: COPING; Italian Stories, Without Bullets

body: IT is probably safe to say that Dr. Robert M. Sapolsky's home is one of the few in America whose cherished family photographs prominently feature baboons. If you crossed Jane Goodall with a borscht belt comedian, she might have written a book like ''A Primate's Memoir: A Neuroscientist's Unconventional Life Among the Baboons'' (Scribner), in which
title: AT HOME WITH: DR. ROBERT M. SAPOLSKY; Family Man With a Foot In the Veld

body: In 1965, Julian Schnabel and I were freshmen at Lafayette High School in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn (Philip Weiss, March 25). Julian was the first to wear bell-bottom pants and Carnaby Street fashions. This invited criticism from students and teachers, and Julian reveled in it. Our art class was memorable. Julian would irritate our teacher
title: Big

body: THE deal on the 3,000-square-foot Brooklyn Heights penthouse apartment -- with its stately dining room, state-of-the-art kitchen, solarium, wraparound terrace and grand views of Manhattan and the harbor -- closed last May at just over $2 million. ''It was the highest price ever paid for a co-op in the Heights,'' said Christopher Thomas, vice
title: Across the City, A Strong Market

author: Catherine Hausman and Victoria Goldman are co-authors of ''The Manhattan Family Guide to Private Schools.'' Ms. Goldman is a board member of the Albert G. Oliver Program.
body: Growing up in Brooklyn, Randolph J. Sealey Jr. never felt like anything other than a typical American kid with an immigrant's background. His grandmother cooked with curry, and he loved baseball and school. ''I was either going to play for the New York Yankees or be a doctor,'' said Mr. Sealey, who arrived in the United States from Panama at age 8.
title: Great Expectations

body: As work on the Mnhattan Bridge scrambles several subway lines this summer, weekend service from Brooklyn into Manhattan will also be significantly reduced, internal transit documents show. The W line, an addition to the subway map that will replace the B line in Brooklyn beginning this summer because of the bridge work, will not run into Manhattan
title: Weekend Cuts In Subway Trips From Brooklyn

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has opened, with the same hours as the museum. This weekend, ''Asian Pacific America: Mixing It Up,'' family programs. Opening tomorrow, ''Involuntary Signs,'' an
title: SPARE TIMES

body: In the days when Coney Island was a summertime playground for millions of American families, Philip's, a little red-and-white candy stand on Surf Avenue, was impossible to bypass. It was the first thing visitors saw as they left the Stillwell Avenue subway terminal, and it was as much a part of the Coney Island experience as a whirl on the Cyclone
title: Pulling Coney Island's Sweet Tooth; As a Landmark Candy Shop Closes, Even Diabetics Mourn

body: IT was late on a Saturday night, a few minutes shy of midnight, when Maritza Gonzalez strode through the door of Club Rio in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. She wore a black lamb's-wool coat with a mink fur collar and black leather boots elevated by four-inch heels. Visible under her coat was a black wrap blouse that revealed ample cleavage and, an inch or
title: For a New Bay Ridge, A New Tony Manero

body: WHEN Arturo Swayze talks about how he transformed a dump, it sounds easy, as if anyone could do it. Describing his technique for creating the new kitchen counter, something that wouldn't look out of place in a Tuscan farmhouse (or at least a showroom for people decorating Tuscan farmhouses) he says it was nothing. ''I just broke up tile and set it
title: Habitats/Dyker Heights, Brooklyn; Fixing Up a Fixer-Upper

body: Downtown yesterday, signs of spring were blooming everywhere. On First Street, a graffiti writer whitewashed a mural to begin anew. On Second Avenue, a bar sign proclaimed, ''It stopped pouring outside; I'm still pouring inside.'' And on Bleecker Street, there was a call of sorts to the open road. Warm weather had returned, and so had a long-gone
title: You Can Take the Hat Out of the Country. . .

body: THE 2000 census hangs numbers on what many New Yorkers already know from the streets: the pulse of the city, and perhaps its future, lies in the boroughs outside Manhattan. As the census figures released last week revealed, the boroughs leaped in population in the past decade -- an 11 percent gain in Queens, 15 percent in Staten Island, 7 percent
title: THE CENSUS UP CLOSE; Behind the Big Numbers, a Million Little Stories

body: THE 2000 census is out and it's official: New York's fastest-growing suburbs are Pike and Monroe Counties. Don't go scrambling for your New York State map. They are in Pennsylvania. That's across the Hudson River, across New Jersey, across the Delaware River and into the Pocono Mountains. If you keep going, you could end up in Ohio. ''We actually
title: Our Towns; Across Two Rivers and Into the Poconos: City Folk Go Country

body: The jurors are likely to hear about a diamond necklace that led to murder and a Brooklyn candy shop that doubled as a gangster den. title: Old-Style Mob Trial for a Murder Case in Brooklyn

body: They called from Los Angeles and Miami. They called from Woodstock, N.Y., and Stamford, Conn. After reading last Sunday about Abraham the homeless dog who scrounged on the streets of Queens, they all wanted to help. There were lifetime offers of food. A woman volunteered to pay his veterinary bills. One man of means considered sending his driver
title: A Furry Vagrant in Astoria Is Rescued by Resolute Hero

body: When she was five and a half months pregnant, Irina Bulycheva, an immigrant from Uzbekistan, fell ill with a fever of 105 degrees. She went into premature labor that lasted 19 hours. title: The Neediest Cases; Struggling Uzbek Family Finds That Americans Are Eager to Help

title: L.I. @ WORK; Cheers! Using Nostalgia to Sell a Brooklyn Soda

body: Alfred A. Allegretti, who transformed his father's one-truck oil dealership beside the Gowanus Canal into one of the largest heating oil companies in the New York metropolitan area, died Jan. 13 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 65 and lived in the Bay Ridge neighborhood of Brooklyn. The cause was prostate cancer, his
title: Alfred Allegretti, 65, Heating Oil Executive

body: Alphonse Persico, the man who federal agents say leads the Colombo crime family, was supposed to become a free man this week, having just completed a 15-month prison sentence in Florida for hiding a 12-gauge shotgun and a semiautomatic pistol aboard his 50-foot yacht, Lookin' Good, in the Florida Keys. title: Reputed Crime Boss Goes From Florida Prison To Brooklyn Court, Never Passing Go

body: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: MORE SMOKING CURBS -- Moving to strengthen rules against smoking, City Council Speaker Peter F. title: METRO BRIEFING

body: The ethnic multiplicity of New York is a beautiful thing, for many reasons. It teaches understanding and tolerance, or at least it should. It makes for great places to eat. It is rarely ever dull. As an added bonus, it can help you get a seat on the subway. The strategy is one that has been used by deft subway seat-getters for as long as there have
title: Tunnel Vision; Using Sociological Radar to Snare a Seat
